Asher
Apr 8

Schedule Changes

“I don’t want to go!” Kayleigh screeched.

Alyssa and Rebecca glanced at each other as Kayleigh began an Olympic-level tantrum on the floor between them.

“Every time,” Rebecca sighed.

“Maybe the next one will be a little less… dramatic,” Alyssa hoped aloud.

“That’s pretty harsh, Ally.”

“Oh, she can’t hear me. And it’s true.”

Kayleigh had managed to kick off her little boots and was struggling to free herself from her raincoat.

“Kayleigh, stop it.” Alyssa had never been known for patience, and children were more taxing than most anything. But Rebecca had wanted to have a child, had talked about it, since long before they were married. Alyssa had relented almost two years ago and, as an anniversary surprise, presented Rebecca with her signature on a Georgia State Parental Initialization Form.

Rebecca had never been more in love with Alyssa than at that moment. The sweetness of that gesture and the hope-filled visions of her dreams of becoming a mother brought her to tears. To this day, if she sat quietly and remembered that evening, she would still get misty eyed.

“Maybe we should upgrade to a new age range. We’ve had Under Fives this whole time.” Rebecca was willing to compromise on almost any detail, but removing themselves from the rotation was inconceivable.

A distinct beeping from the kitchen silenced everyone, even Kayleigh. Rebecca and Alyssa exchanged a look of dread. Kayleigh started to smile.

“I’ll go check. I swear, if they do this to us again…” Alyssa said as she stomped off to the kitchen.

The wall-mounted tablet-sized digital calendar was flashing orange and emitting the “urgent alert” beeping pattern that had become all to familiar. Alyssa pulled her glasses from her forehead and tapped the silence button.

“URGENT MESSAGE: NY-Kayleigh-2258: RELOCATION DELAY: NEW TRANSFER DATE — 27MAY2022. TAP HERE TO ACKNOWLEDGE”

“Dammit!” Alyssa yelled. “Another three weeks!”

“Yaaaaay!!!” Kayleigh giggled with delight. She snatched up her backpack and ran off to the bedroom to unpack.

Rebecca joined Alyssa in the kitchen and read the message for herself. “It’s only three weeks, Ally. It won’t be that bad.”

“They keep doing this. I just can’t take it anymore, the delays.” Alyssa was on the verge of tears.

“Well. We can decline the extension. But we’ll lose points and Kayleigh will end up in a holding facility — and, honey, those are horrible.” Rebecca would beg if she had to. “I don’t think I could do that to her. Please, honey. God knows when she’d get back in rotation. And we’d lose our selection priority.”

“We should at least register a complaint. I’m pinging them.” Alyssa frustratedly tapped the acknowledgement and navigated to the “Contact GS Parental Services — Nonemergency” screen. She tapped the screen to enter the required information and straightened her hair as she watched the annoying “connecting…” animation’s infinite loop. After several seconds, a pleasant young man’s face appeared on the screen beside the calendar. “Camera Broadcasting” flashed at the top of the calendar, alerting them that their kitchen was temporarily not private.

“Hello. I’m Marcus. How may I help you, Miss Riley?” the young man said in a kind-but-scripted tone.

“We just received another delay notice, last minute like always. And it’s Mrs., thank you.” Alyssa was working hard to keep her frustration in check — unsuccessfully.

“I understand, Mrs. Riley. Apologies for that. Would you mind holding while I retrieve your account information?”

“Of course. Sure.”

Kayleigh could be heard in the background, laughing, bouncing on the bed (her go-to activity) and excitedly talking to the stuffed animals in her room.

“Honey, I just can’t stand it any more. I need peace and quiet. Just for a little while.” Alyssa whispered to Rebecca.

“Shhhh. He’ll hear you,” Rebecca whispered back, trying not to move her lips.

“Mrs. Riley, I have your account information on my screen now. Let’s see…. Ah. Yes. Could you please confirm that your currently assigned juvenile is NY-Kayleigh-2258?”

“Yes. That’s her.”

“I’m sorry. We require that you tap the ‘confirm’ button at the bottom right of your screen,” Marcus instructed.

“Oh. Right.” Alyssa tapped ‘confirm.’

“Thank you, Mrs. Riley. And, let’s see… it’ looks like she was scheduled to transfer to the next parental participants in her rotation… Oh! Wow! Today.”

“Exactly. ‘Wow today.’ We just about had her out the door and you messaged us with the change notice.” The bureaucratic process was not helping Alyssa’s frustration.

“I apologize for the inconvenience, Mrs. Riley. It looks like the next parental participants in her rotation have opted out of the program.”

“So we’re stuck with her?”

“Ally, shh!” Rebecca scolded.

“Is there a problem with your juvenile, Mrs. Riley? Would you like to record an incident?” Marcus’ tone was beginning to shift.

“Yes.”

“No!” Rebecca countered. She reached up and covered the camera with her hand. “I swear to God Ally, if you cause that girl to get pulled into one of those disgusting holding facilities I will never speak to you again.”

“Move your hand,” Alyssa said. Rebecca hesitantly complied. “I’m sorry, sir. I misunderstood the question. There’s no need to record an incident.”

“Alright,” Marcus said, softening a bit. “How can we help you, then?”

“Is there anyone else that can take her?” Alyssa asked, trying to sound more nonchalant than she felt.

“I’m sorry, Mrs. Riley.” Marcus began to read something in front of him. It was obvious he has this conversation several times a day. “As you know, the program maintains a precise balance of approved parental participants to juveniles. The Overpopulation Abatement Act of 2019 requires strict matching of vetted parental participants and registered juveniles. During Phase 1 of the OAA, we are experiencing more juveniles than parental participants and our holding facilities are constantly overcrowded. As government oversight and enforcement of progeneration guidelines becomes more efficient we expect this current challenge to decrease. We ask for your patience in the meantime.”

“So you’re saying there’s nothing we can do.” Alyssa had heard this message before.

“We do have options available for parental participants who are no longer able or willing to complete their contractual obligations. If you’ll look to the left side of your screen, just under the calendar view, you should see a list of options. Simply tap one to select it. Feel free to ask if you have any questions. I’m here to help.”

Kayleigh was still gleefully (and more loudly) playing in her room. The Rileys were her favorite of all the parental participants she’s had since her mother accepted the government’s offer. Fifty thousand dollars was a lot of money to the single mother. And she’d never really wanted children so the required sterilization didn’t concern her at all. She also found peace knowing that Kayleigh would be loved by up to eight sets of parental participants and would have a clearly prescribed path to becoming a nurse, according to her genetic profile and early assessments. (Those were more than 97% accurate.)

Alyssa caught Rebecca’s eye. “Honey, please go calm her down. I’ll finish here.”

“Sure. Three weeks will pass fast, Ally. I’ll make sure you have peace and quiet, I promise.” Rebecca gave Alyssa a peck on the cheek and jogged off to Kayleigh’s room and closed the door.

Alyssa focused on the screen. A list of option buttons ran down the left side.

‘A: Request escalation. A supervisor will review your case and call you within one business day.’
‘B: Request GSPSA to reclaim juvenile. Allow two days for pickup.’
‘C: Request URGENT reclamation by GSPSA or Local Law Enforcement. Fee may apply.’
‘D: Terminate Parental Participation contract.’
“E: Cancel call. Take no action.”

Alyssa stared at the screen. She read and reread each option several times.

“Do you have any questions, Mrs. Riley?” Marcus asked.

“No. These are clear.” She stared a moment longer. She could hear Kayleigh and Rebecca giddily chasing each other in the bedroom. She closed her eyes and tapped the screen.

“Thank you, Mrs. Riley. A car will be by within four hours. Please have your juvenile’s personal belongings gathered in one place. Is there anything else I can help you with?”

“No. Thank you.”

The camera warning vanished and the calendar reclaimed the entire screen. Alyssa exhaled loudly. She stood still for a moment, gathering her thoughts. She walked down the hallway, towards the laughter, dreading what was coming next.

Thanks to Aura Wilming and S Lynn Knight.
